posts.title: Autism: Practical Daily Strategies for Adults and Families
posts.excerpt: Evidence-informed approaches to support autistic individuals in managing sensory sensitivities, routines, and social communication in everyday life.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Autism Spectrum Condition

Autism is a lifelong neurodevelopmental condition affecting how people communicate, interact, and experience the world. It is not a disease requiring a cure, but rather a different way of being that comes with both strengths and challenges.

According to the National Autistic Society, over 700,000 people in the UK are autistic — that's more than 1 in 100. Many autistic adults remain undiagnosed, particularly women and those without learning disabilities.

Practical Daily Strategies

Sensory Management

  • Identify your sensory sensitivities (sound, light, texture, smell, taste)
  • Create a sensory toolkit: noise-cancelling headphones, sunglasses, fidget tools, comfort items
  • Plan sensory breaks throughout your day
  • Communicate your needs to family, friends, and colleagues
  • Use the Zones of Regulation framework to monitor your sensory state

Routines and Predictability

  • Establish consistent daily routines (wake time, meals, bedtime)
  • Use visual schedules or calendar apps with alerts
  • Prepare for changes in advance when possible
  • Create 'transition rituals' between activities (e.g., 5-minute warning + deep breathing)
  • Have a 'Plan B' ready for unexpected changes

Social Communication

  • It's okay to take breaks from social situations when overwhelmed
  • Practice scripts for common social situations if helpful
  • Communicate your preferences: 'I prefer direct communication' or 'I need time to process'
  • Seek out neurodivergent-friendly spaces and communities
  • Remember: unmasking is a gradual process, and you get to choose when and where

At Work or School

  • Request reasonable adjustments under the Equality Act 2010 (UK)
  • Examples: flexible hours, quiet workspace, written instructions, task breakdowns
  • Use tools like noise-cancelling headphones or desk partitions
  • Schedule regular check-ins with your line manager or tutor
  • Access workplace or university disability services

When to Seek Support

Contact your GP if:

  • You suspect you may be autistic and want to pursue diagnosis
  • You're experiencing mental health difficulties (anxiety, depression, burnout)
  • Daily living becomes significantly more challenging

In a mental health crisis: Contact NHS 111 (option 2 for mental health), Samaritans (116 123), or in emergency, call 999.

Important Disclaimer

This information is for educational purposes only and does not replace professional medical advice. Autism presents differently in every individual. Always consult your GP or a qualified clinician for personalised assessment and support.

posts.title: ADHD: Evidence-Based Focus and Organisation Strategies
posts.excerpt: Practical, non-medication approaches to managing attention, executive function, and time management for adults and young people with ADHD.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding ADHD

Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is a neurodevelopmental condition affecting executive function — the brain's 'management system' responsible for planning, focus, impulse control, and time perception.

ADHD affects approximately 5% of children and 2-4% of adults in the UK (NICE, 2018). It is not caused by poor parenting, laziness, or lack of discipline. ADHD brains have measurable differences in structure and neurotransmitter function.

Practical Focus Strategies

External Structure and Cues

  • Use visual timers (Time Timer, Pomodoro apps) to make time tangible
  • Break tasks into 5-15 minute 'micro-sessions' with movement breaks
  • Create physical 'stations' for different activities (work desk, reading chair, creative space)
  • Use colour-coding for priority levels (urgent = red, important = amber, routine = green)
  • Set multiple alarms for transitions and deadlines

Working Memory Support

  • Externalise everything: write it down immediately (phone, notebook, whiteboard)
  • Use the '2-minute rule': if it takes under 2 minutes, do it now
  • Keep a single 'master list' rather than multiple scattered notes
  • Voice memos for ideas that come when you can't write
  • Create checklists for recurring tasks (morning routine, leaving the house, project steps)

Environment Optimisation

  • Reduce visual clutter in work/study space
  • Use noise-cancelling headphones or brown noise/lo-fi music if helpful
  • Face a wall rather than a window if external movement distracts you
  • Keep fidget tools accessible (stress ball, fidget cube, blu-tack)
  • Have a 'dopamine menu' — list of quick, engaging activities for motivation slumps

Managing Hyperfocus

  • Set 'hyperfocus boundaries': alarms for meals, breaks, sleep
  • Pair hyperfocus-prone activities with timers or accountability partners
  • Recognise hyperfocus as a strength when channelled intentionally
  • Don't fight it when it's useful, but protect basic needs (food, water, rest)

Reasonable Adjustments at Work/School (UK)

Under the Equality Act 2010, you can request:

  • Written instructions and meeting agendas in advance
  • Extra time for tasks or exams
  • Flexible working hours (e.g., start later if morning executive function is difficult)
  • Permission to use fidget tools or take movement breaks
  • Regular check-ins with clear, concrete feedback
  • Reduced open-plan workspace noise (quiet room, remote work options)

When to Seek Support

Contact your GP if:

  • You suspect ADHD but don't have a diagnosis (referral to specialist assessment)
  • Current strategies aren't sufficient and you want to explore medication
  • You're experiencing significant distress or impairment in daily functioning
  • Co-occurring conditions (anxiety, depression, sleep problems) need addressing

Crisis support: NHS 111 (option 2), Samaritans (116 123), or 999 in emergencies.

Important Disclaimer

This information is educational and not medical advice. ADHD management is highly individual. Medication can be effective for many people and should be discussed with a qualified prescriber. Do not start or stop medication without clinical guidance.

posts.title: Dyslexia: Reading, Writing, and Learning Support Strategies
posts.excerpt: Evidence-based approaches to support individuals with dyslexia in reading, writing, organisation, and accessing education or workplace accommodations.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Dyslexia

Dyslexia is a specific learning difficulty that primarily affects reading and writing skills. It is not related to intelligence — many people with dyslexia have average or above-average IQ. Dyslexia affects approximately 10% of the UK population (British Dyslexia Association).

Dyslexia is neurological in origin and results from differences in how the brain processes written and spoken language. It is lifelong, but with the right support, people with dyslexia can thrive academically and professionally.

Practical Strategies for Reading and Writing

Reading Support

  • Use a coloured overlay or tinted glasses if visual stress/Irlen syndrome is present
  • Try dyslexia-friendly fonts (OpenDyslexic, Comic Sans, Arial) with increased line spacing (1.5–2.0)
  • Break text into smaller chunks; use a ruler or reading guide to track lines
  • Listen to audiobooks alongside reading (multimodal learning)
  • Pre-read summaries or watch videos about the topic before tackling full text
  • Use text-to-speech software (Immersive Reader, NaturalReader, Voice Dream)

Writing Support

  • Use speech-to-text software (Dragon NaturallySpeaking, Google Docs voice typing)
  • Plan writing with mind maps or bullet points before drafting
  • Use grammar and spell-check tools (Grammarly, Read&Write, Ginger)
  • Break large writing tasks into smaller sections with breaks between
  • Don't worry about perfect spelling in first drafts — focus on ideas first, editing later
  • Record voice notes of ideas, then transcribe or expand later

Organisation and Memory

  • Use visual timetables, colour-coded calendars, and phone reminders
  • Keep a 'second brain' (notebook, app) for important information
  • Use mnemonics, rhymes, or stories to remember sequences
  • Take photos of whiteboards, handouts, or important info rather than relying on notes
  • Create checklists for routines (morning, packing bag, assignments)

Assistive Technology

  • Text-to-speech: Immersive Reader (built into Microsoft products), NaturalReader
  • Speech-to-text: Dragon, Google Docs voice typing, Apple Dictation
  • Reading aids: Read&Write, ClaroRead, Voice Dream Reader
  • Note-taking: Notability, OneNote (with audio recording), Otter.ai
  • Mind mapping: MindMeister, Coggle, SimpleMind

Support at School (UK)

Under the Equality Act 2010 and SEND Code of Practice, children with dyslexia are entitled to reasonable adjustments:

  • Extra time in exams (typically 25%)
  • Access to a reader, scribe, or word processor
  • Printed materials in dyslexia-friendly format
  • Individualised learning plan or Education, Health and Care Plan (EHCP) if needed
  • Specialist dyslexia tuition (structured literacy approaches like Orton-Gillingham)
  • Breaks during long tasks; reduced copying from board

Parents/carers: Contact your school's SENCO (Special Educational Needs Coordinator) to request assessment and support. You can also request an Educational Psychology assessment via your local authority.

Support at Work (UK)

Under the Equality Act 2010, employees with dyslexia can request workplace adjustments:

  • Access to assistive technology (software, coloured overlays)
  • Written instructions for tasks; meeting agendas in advance
  • Extra time for reading/writing tasks
  • Use of voice recording in meetings
  • Dyslexia awareness training for colleagues and managers
  • Access to quiet spaces for focused work

Access to Work: A UK government scheme that can fund workplace assessments and assistive technology for employees with disabilities, including dyslexia.

When to Seek Support

Contact your GP or educational psychologist if:

  • You or your child struggle significantly with reading, writing, or spelling despite appropriate teaching
  • There are signs of anxiety, low self-esteem, or school refusal related to literacy tasks
  • You need a formal dyslexia assessment for school or workplace accommodations

Where to get assessed: Educational psychologists (via school or privately), specialist dyslexia teachers, or dyslexia assessment centres accredited by the British Dyslexia Association.

Important Disclaimer

This information is for educational purposes and does not replace professional assessment or educational advice. Dyslexia presents differently in every individual. Consult a qualified specialist for personalised support and formal diagnosis.

posts.title: Bipolar Disorder: Mood Monitoring and Stability Strategies
posts.excerpt: Practical approaches to recognising mood patterns, maintaining stability, and managing bipolar disorder alongside medical treatment.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Bipolar Disorder

Bipolar disorder is a mental health condition characterised by significant mood swings, including manic or hypomanic episodes (elevated mood, increased energy) and depressive episodes (low mood, low energy). It affects approximately 1-2% of the UK population.

Bipolar disorder is a lifelong condition, but with appropriate treatment (typically a combination of medication and psychological therapy), most people can manage their symptoms and live fulfilling lives.

Types of Bipolar Disorder

  • Bipolar I: At least one manic episode (lasting 7+ days or severe enough to require hospitalisation), often with depressive episodes
  • Bipolar II: Hypomanic episodes (less severe than mania) and depressive episodes, but no full manic episodes
  • Cyclothymia: Frequent mood swings over at least 2 years, but less severe than bipolar I or II

Practical Mood Monitoring Strategies

Daily Mood Tracking

  • Use a mood diary or app (Daylio, eMoods, Bipolar UK Mood Tracker)
  • Track mood, sleep, energy, activities, and triggers daily
  • Rate mood on a scale (e.g., -5 to +5, with 0 as baseline)
  • Note early warning signs of mood shifts
  • Share mood charts with your care team regularly

Recognising Early Warning Signs

Mania/Hypomania warning signs:

  • Reduced need for sleep (feeling rested on 3-4 hours)
  • Rapid thoughts, racing speech, increased talkativeness
  • Increased goal-directed activity or impulsive decisions
  • Increased spending, risk-taking, or sexual activity
  • Irritability or feeling 'wired'

Depression warning signs:

  • Difficulty getting out of bed, increased sleep
  • Loss of interest in activities you usually enjoy
  • Feelings of hopelessness, worthlessness, or guilt
  • Difficulty concentrating or making decisions
  • Thoughts of self-harm or suicide

Maintaining Stability

  • Sleep regularity: Go to bed and wake at the same time daily; prioritise 7-9 hours
  • Routine: Keep consistent daily structure (meals, activities, social contact)
  • Avoid triggers: Identify and minimise personal triggers (alcohol, drugs, stress, sleep deprivation)
  • Medication adherence: Take prescribed medication consistently; never stop suddenly without medical guidance
  • Social rhythm: Maintain regular social activities and commitments

Relapse Prevention Plan

  • Work with your care team to create a written relapse prevention plan
  • Include: early warning signs, emergency contacts, helpful strategies, medication details
  • Share your plan with trusted friends/family who can spot warning signs
  • Review and update your plan regularly with your psychiatrist or care coordinator

Psychological Therapies

Evidence-based therapies for bipolar disorder include:

  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT): Identifying and changing unhelpful thought patterns
  • Interpersonal and Social Rhythm Therapy (IPSRT): Stabilising daily routines and social rhythms
  • Family-Focused Therapy: Improving family communication and support
  • Psychoeducation: Learning about bipolar disorder, triggers, and management strategies

When to Seek Urgent Help

Contact your care team or GP urgently if:

  • You notice early warning signs of mania or depression
  • You're having thoughts of self-harm or suicide
  • Your mood is significantly affecting daily functioning
  • You're considering stopping medication

In a crisis:

  • Contact your Crisis Team (if you have one)
  • Call NHS 111 and select option 2 for mental health
  • Call Samaritans (116 123, 24/7)
  • Go to A&E or call 999 if at immediate risk

Important Disclaimer

This information is educational and not a substitute for medical advice. Bipolar disorder requires professional diagnosis and treatment. Never stop medication or change doses without consulting your psychiatrist or GP. Always seek medical guidance for personalised care.

posts.title: Depression: Self-Care and Evidence-Based Coping Strategies
posts.excerpt: Practical approaches to managing depression through behavioural activation, thought patterns, sleep, and knowing when to seek professional support.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Depression

Depression (also called major depressive disorder or clinical depression) is more than feeling sad or having a 'bad day'. It is a persistent low mood lasting at least two weeks, affecting how you think, feel, and manage daily activities.

Depression is common — approximately 1 in 6 adults in the UK experience depression in any given week (Mental Health Foundation). It is not a sign of weakness, and it is treatable with the right support.

Common Symptoms

  • Persistent sadness, emptiness, or hopelessness
  • Loss of interest or pleasure in activities
  • Changes in appetite or weight
  • Sleep problems (insomnia or oversleeping)
  • Fatigue or loss of energy
  • Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
  • Difficulty concentrating or making decisions
  • Thoughts of death or suicide

Evidence-Based Self-Care Strategies

Behavioural Activation

Behavioural activation is a core component of CBT for depression. It involves gradually re-engaging with activities, even when motivation is low.

  • Schedule one small, achievable activity each day (walk, shower, call a friend)
  • Start with activities that are easy or used to bring you pleasure
  • Break tasks into tiny steps (e.g., 'put on shoes' before 'go for walk')
  • Track activities and mood — notice patterns of what helps
  • Don't wait to 'feel motivated' — action often comes before motivation

Thought Patterns

  • Notice negative automatic thoughts (e.g., 'I'm useless', 'Nothing will get better')
  • Ask: 'Is this thought based on facts or feelings?'
  • Look for evidence for and against the thought
  • Reframe: 'I'm struggling right now, but depression is treatable'
  • Practice self-compassion: speak to yourself as you would a friend

Sleep Hygiene

  • Keep a consistent sleep schedule (same bedtime and wake time)
  • Get natural light in the morning (opens curtains, brief outdoor time)
  • Limit screen time 1 hour before bed
  • Avoid long daytime naps (or keep to 20-30 minutes before 3pm)
  • Create a calming bedtime routine

Physical Health

  • Move your body daily, even briefly (10-minute walk, stretching, dancing)
  • Eat regular, balanced meals (depression can affect appetite)
  • Stay hydrated
  • Limit alcohol (it worsens depression)
  • Spend time outdoors when possible

Social Connection

  • Reach out to one person each week (text, call, or meet)
  • Join a support group (Mind, Depression Alliance, online communities)
  • Be honest with trusted people about how you're feeling
  • Accept help when offered
  • If face-to-face feels too much, start with text or voice notes

Professional Support

Psychological Therapies

  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT): Identifying and changing unhelpful thought patterns
  • Behavioural Activation: Structured re-engagement with meaningful activities
  • Interpersonal Therapy (IPT): Addressing relationship difficulties contributing to depression
  • Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT): Preventing relapse in recurrent depression

Access via your GP (NHS Talking Therapies, formerly IAPT), private therapist, or charity services (Mind, Rethink Mental Illness).

Medication

Antidepressants can be effective, particularly for moderate to severe depression. Discuss options with your GP. Common types include SSRIs (e.g., sertraline, fluoxetine) and SNRIs. Medication typically takes 4-6 weeks to work fully.

When to Seek Urgent Help

Contact your GP if:

  • Low mood persists for more than 2 weeks
  • Depression is affecting work, relationships, or daily life
  • You're experiencing thoughts of self-harm or suicide

In a crisis:

  • Call NHS 111 (option 2 for mental health crisis)
  • Call Samaritans (116 123, 24/7, free)
  • Text SHOUT to 85258 (free crisis text line)
  • Go to A&E or call 999 if at immediate risk

Important Disclaimer

This information is for educational purposes and not a substitute for medical advice. Depression is a clinical condition requiring professional assessment and treatment. If you are experiencing symptoms, please contact your GP or NHS 111.

posts.title: Anxiety: Practical Techniques for Managing Worry and Panic
posts.excerpt: Evidence-based strategies for managing generalised anxiety, panic attacks, and worry, including breathing techniques, grounding, and thought reframing.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Anxiety

Anxiety is the body's natural response to perceived threat or danger. Everyone experiences anxiety sometimes, but when it becomes persistent, overwhelming, or interferes with daily life, it may be an anxiety disorder.

Anxiety disorders are the most common mental health condition in the UK, affecting approximately 1 in 6 adults each week. They are highly treatable with the right support.

Types of Anxiety

  • Generalised Anxiety Disorder (GAD): Persistent, excessive worry about various aspects of life
  • Panic Disorder: Recurrent unexpected panic attacks and fear of future attacks
  • Social Anxiety: Intense fear of social situations and being judged by others
  • Phobias: Intense fear of specific objects or situations

Practical Anxiety Management Strategies

Breathing Techniques

  • 4-7-8 Breathing: Breathe in for 4 counts, hold for 7, exhale for 8
  • Box Breathing: Breathe in for 4, hold for 4, out for 4, hold for 4
  • Diaphragmatic breathing: Breathe deeply into your belly (not chest)
  • Practice daily, not just during anxiety — builds the skill
  • Use breathing as your 'anchor' when anxiety rises

Grounding Techniques (for panic or overwhelm)

  • 5-4-3-2-1 technique: Name 5 things you see, 4 you can touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste
  • Physical grounding: Press feet into floor, hold ice cube, splash cold water on face
  • Mental grounding: Count backwards from 100 by 7s, name countries alphabetically, recite a poem
  • Soothing grounding: Imagine a safe place, hug yourself, use a comfort object

Challenging Anxious Thoughts

  • Identify the worry: 'What exactly am I afraid will happen?'
  • Is it likely? What's the evidence for and against?
  • What's the worst that could happen? Could I cope with that?
  • What would I tell a friend in this situation?
  • Reframe: 'I feel anxious' instead of 'Something bad will happen'

Worry Time

  • Schedule 15-20 minutes daily as 'worry time'
  • When worries arise during the day, write them down for worry time
  • During worry time, review worries: Which need action? Which are hypothetical?
  • After worry time, use distraction or grounding to move on

Lifestyle Factors

  • Limit caffeine and stimulants (they can trigger anxiety)
  • Avoid alcohol (it worsens anxiety once it wears off)
  • Regular exercise (20-30 minutes most days reduces anxiety)
  • Sleep 7-9 hours per night (fatigue worsens anxiety)
  • Eat regular, balanced meals (low blood sugar can mimic anxiety symptoms)

Exposure (for avoidance-based anxiety)

Gradual, repeated exposure to feared situations reduces anxiety over time. This is a core part of CBT.

  • Make a 'fear ladder': list feared situations from least to most scary
  • Start with the easiest item and practice repeatedly until anxiety reduces
  • Move up the ladder gradually
  • Don't leave situations at peak anxiety — stay until anxiety reduces by at least 50%
  • Seek professional support for exposure therapy if needed

Managing Panic Attacks

Panic attacks are sudden surges of intense fear, often with physical symptoms (rapid heartbeat, sweating, shaking, feeling faint). They peak within 10 minutes and are not dangerous.

  • Remind yourself: 'This is a panic attack. It's uncomfortable but not dangerous. It will pass.'
  • Focus on slow, controlled breathing (4-7-8 or box breathing)
  • Stay where you are if possible (leaving reinforces avoidance)
  • Use grounding techniques (5-4-3-2-1)
  • Ride the wave — don't fight it

Professional Support

Psychological Therapies

  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT): First-line treatment for anxiety disorders
  • Exposure Therapy: For phobias, panic disorder, social anxiety
  • Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT): Learning to accept anxious feelings rather than fighting them

Access via NHS Talking Therapies (via GP), private therapist, or Anxiety UK.

Medication

SSRIs (e.g., sertraline) are commonly prescribed for anxiety disorders. Short-term benzodiazepines may be used in crisis but are not recommended long-term. Discuss options with your GP.

When to Seek Help

Contact your GP if:

  • Anxiety is affecting daily life, work, or relationships
  • You're avoiding important activities due to anxiety
  • You're experiencing frequent panic attacks
  • Self-help strategies aren't sufficient

In a crisis:

  • Call NHS 111 (option 2 for mental health)
  • Call Samaritans (116 123) or Anxiety UK Helpline (03444 775 774)
  • Text SHOUT to 85258
  • Go to A&E if at immediate risk

Important Disclaimer

This information is for educational purposes and not medical advice. Anxiety disorders require professional assessment. If symptoms persist or worsen, contact your GP for personalised support.

posts.title: Stress and Burnout: Recognition, Prevention, and Recovery
posts.excerpt: Practical strategies for managing chronic stress, recognising burnout, setting boundaries, and building resilience in work and personal life.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Stress and Burnout

Stress is the body's response to pressure or demands. Short-term stress can be motivating, but chronic stress is harmful to physical and mental health.

Burnout is a state of emotional, physical, and mental exhaustion caused by prolonged or excessive stress, particularly work-related. It's characterised by feeling depleted, cynical, and ineffective.

74% of UK adults have felt so stressed at some point in the past year that they felt overwhelmed or unable to cope (Mental Health Foundation, 2018).

Recognising Burnout

Three Core Dimensions

  • Exhaustion: Feeling drained, depleted, unable to recover even with rest
  • Cynicism/Detachment: Feeling distant, negative, or numb about work or responsibilities
  • Reduced Efficacy: Feeling ineffective, doubting your abilities, decreased productivity

Physical and Emotional Signs

  • Chronic fatigue, sleep problems, frequent illness
  • Headaches, muscle tension, digestive issues
  • Irritability, mood swings, loss of motivation
  • Difficulty concentrating, memory problems
  • Withdrawal from social activities or responsibilities
  • Using food, alcohol, or substances to cope

Practical Stress Management Strategies

Daily Stress Reduction

  • Practice breathing exercises daily (4-7-8, box breathing)
  • Take regular breaks (5 minutes every hour, walk away from screen)
  • Move your body (walk, stretch, yoga, any physical activity)
  • Spend time in nature, even briefly
  • Limit news and social media consumption
  • Maintain a consistent sleep schedule

Setting Boundaries

  • Define 'work hours' and 'personal time' — protect personal time
  • Turn off work notifications outside work hours
  • Practice saying 'no' or 'not right now' to additional commitments
  • Communicate boundaries clearly and calmly
  • Delegate tasks where possible
  • Schedule 'white space' — unstructured downtime

Time Management

  • Prioritise tasks: urgent vs. important (Eisenhower Matrix)
  • Break large tasks into smaller, manageable steps
  • Use the '2-minute rule': if it takes under 2 minutes, do it now
  • Batch similar tasks together
  • Schedule focused work time (no interruptions)
  • Accept 'good enough' — perfectionism fuels burnout

Building Resilience

  • Identify personal values and align actions with them
  • Maintain social connections (regular contact with friends/family)
  • Engage in hobbies or activities unrelated to work
  • Practice self-compassion (speak kindly to yourself)
  • Reframe challenges as learning opportunities
  • Seek meaning and purpose in daily activities

Recovery from Burnout

Recovering from burnout takes time and often requires significant changes. Self-care alone is not enough if systemic workplace issues are the root cause.

Short-Term Recovery Steps

  • Take time off if possible (sick leave, annual leave)
  • Rest without guilt — burnout is a health issue
  • Reconnect with enjoyable, non-work activities
  • Talk to someone you trust (friend, therapist, occupational health)
  • Reduce commitments temporarily

Long-Term Changes

  • Assess workload: Is it sustainable? Can tasks be redistributed?
  • Address toxic work culture: Speak to HR, manager, or consider leaving
  • Renegotiate role expectations or working hours
  • Access occupational health or employee assistance programmes
  • Consider a career change or sabbatical if needed

Workplace Support (UK)

Your Rights

  • Working Time Regulations: Right to rest breaks, limits on working hours
  • Health and Safety at Work Act: Employers must manage work-related stress risks
  • Equality Act 2010: If stress causes or worsens a disability (e.g., depression, anxiety), you may be entitled to reasonable adjustments

Requesting Support

  • Request a stress risk assessment or occupational health referral
  • Discuss workload concerns with your line manager or HR
  • Access Employee Assistance Programmes (EAP) if available
  • Contact ACAS (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service) for workplace rights advice
  • Speak to your union representative if applicable

When to Seek Professional Help

Contact your GP if:

  • Stress or burnout is affecting your physical or mental health
  • You're experiencing symptoms of depression or anxiety
  • You're using substances to cope
  • Sleep problems persist
  • You're unable to function in daily life or work

Therapy options: CBT, Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT), stress management courses. Access via NHS Talking Therapies or private therapist.

In a crisis: NHS 111 (option 2), Samaritans (116 123), or 999 if at immediate risk.

Important Disclaimer

This information is for educational purposes and not medical or legal advice. Chronic stress and burnout are health issues requiring professional support. Consult your GP, occupational health, or a therapist for personalised care.

posts.title: Sleep Difficulties: Evidence-Based Strategies for Better Rest
posts.excerpt: Practical approaches to improving sleep quality, managing insomnia, and establishing healthy sleep habits for adults and adolescents.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Sleep Difficulties

Sleep problems are common — approximately 1 in 3 UK adults experience insomnia symptoms. Poor sleep affects mood, concentration, physical health, and overall quality of life.

Insomnia is difficulty falling asleep, staying asleep, or waking too early, occurring at least 3 nights per week for 3+ months and causing daytime impairment.

Why Sleep Matters

  • Physical health: immune function, metabolism, heart health
  • Mental health: mood regulation, emotional resilience
  • Cognitive function: memory consolidation, concentration, decision-making
  • Neurodevelopmental conditions: Sleep problems are common in ADHD, autism, anxiety

Evidence-Based Sleep Strategies

Sleep Hygiene Basics

  • Consistent schedule: Go to bed and wake at the same time daily (including weekends)
  • Sleep environment: Cool (16-18°C), dark, quiet bedroom
  • Comfortable bed: Supportive mattress and pillows
  • No screens 1 hour before bed: Blue light suppresses melatonin
  • Limit caffeine after 2pm: Caffeine stays in system for 6+ hours
  • Avoid alcohol before bed: It disrupts sleep architecture

Daytime Habits

  • Get natural light exposure in the morning (helps regulate circadian rhythm)
  • Exercise regularly, but not within 3 hours of bedtime
  • Limit daytime naps (or keep to 20-30 minutes before 3pm)
  • Avoid large meals close to bedtime
  • Manage stress during the day (not at bedtime)

Wind-Down Routine

  • Start winding down 1 hour before bed
  • Dim lights, switch to relaxing activities (reading, gentle stretching, music)
  • Try a warm bath or shower (body temperature drop afterwards aids sleep)
  • Practice breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation
  • Write a 'worry list' or tomorrow's to-do list to clear your mind

Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I)

CBT-I is the first-line treatment for chronic insomnia, more effective than medication in the long term.

Key components:

  • Stimulus control: Use bed only for sleep (not work, TV, worrying)
  • Sleep restriction: Limit time in bed to actual sleep time (builds sleep pressure)
  • Cognitive therapy: Challenge unhelpful beliefs about sleep
  • Relaxation training: Progressive muscle relaxation, breathing exercises
  • Sleep hygiene: As above

Access CBT-I via NHS Talking Therapies, Sleepio (digital CBT-I available on NHS), or private therapist.

If You Can't Sleep

  • If awake for 20+ minutes, get out of bed
  • Go to another room, do something calm and boring in low light
  • Return to bed when you feel sleepy
  • Repeat as needed — don't lie awake for hours
  • Avoid checking the time (increases anxiety)

Sleep and Mental Health

Sleep problems and mental health conditions have a bidirectional relationship — poor sleep worsens mental health, and mental health difficulties worsen sleep.

  • If you have depression or anxiety, prioritise sleep as part of recovery
  • If nightmares or trauma-related sleep problems occur, seek trauma-focused therapy (e.g., EMDR, trauma-focused CBT)
  • For ADHD-related sleep issues, consider melatonin (discuss with GP)

When to Seek Professional Help

Contact your GP if:

  • Sleep problems persist despite self-help strategies
  • Insomnia is affecting daytime functioning
  • You suspect a sleep disorder (sleep apnoea, restless legs syndrome, narcolepsy)
  • You're experiencing excessive daytime sleepiness
  • Sleep problems are affecting your mental health

Medication

Sleeping tablets (e.g., zopiclone) are only recommended short-term (2-4 weeks) for acute insomnia. Long-term use is not recommended due to dependence and tolerance. Melatonin may be prescribed for specific groups (e.g., ADHD, older adults). Discuss with your GP.

Sleep and Neurodivergence

ADHD and Sleep

  • ADHD medications can affect sleep — discuss timing with GP
  • Use external cues (alarms, visual schedules) for bedtime routine
  • Melatonin may be helpful (prescribed by GP)

Autism and Sleep

  • Use blackout curtains, white noise machines, weighted blankets if helpful
  • Create a highly predictable bedtime routine
  • Visual schedules for sleep routine
  • Address sensory sensitivities (bedding texture, temperature, sounds)

Important Disclaimer

This information is for educational purposes and not medical advice. Persistent sleep problems or suspected sleep disorders require professional assessment. Consult your GP or sleep specialist for personalised support.

posts.title: Emotional Regulation: Skills for Managing Intense Emotions
posts.excerpt: Evidence-based techniques for recognising, understanding, and managing intense emotions across neurodevelopmental and mental health conditions.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Emotional Regulation

Emotional regulation is the ability to recognise, understand, and manage emotions in healthy ways. Difficulties with emotional regulation are common across many conditions, including ADHD, autism, anxiety, depression, and trauma.

Emotional dysregulation can present as: intense emotional reactions, difficulty calming down, rapid mood shifts, impulsive behaviour, or emotional numbness.

Why Emotional Regulation is Challenging

  • Neurodevelopmental differences: ADHD and autism can affect emotional processing and impulse control
  • Trauma history: Past trauma can dysregulate the nervous system
  • Mental health conditions: Anxiety and depression affect emotional intensity and recovery
  • Lack of skills: Emotional regulation is a learned skill, not always taught explicitly

The Emotional Regulation Cycle

  1. Awareness: Recognising what you're feeling
  2. Understanding: Identifying why you're feeling this way
  3. Acceptance: Allowing the emotion without judgment
  4. Modulation: Using skills to manage intensity
  5. Recovery: Returning to baseline

Practical Emotional Regulation Skills

Emotion Awareness

  • Name the emotion: 'I feel angry' or 'I feel overwhelmed'
  • Rate intensity on a scale (0-10)
  • Notice where you feel it in your body (chest, stomach, head)
  • Identify the trigger: 'What happened just before I felt this?'
  • Use an emotions wheel to expand emotional vocabulary

Grounding Techniques (for intense emotions)

  • 5-4-3-2-1: Name 5 things you see, 4 you touch, 3 you hear, 2 you smell, 1 you taste
  • Cold water: Splash face, hold ice cube, drink cold water
  • Physical grounding: Stomp feet, press hands together, do wall push-ups
  • Breathing: 4-7-8 breathing, box breathing, paced breathing
  • Containment: Imagine putting the emotion in a container to deal with later

DBT TIPP Skills (for crisis moments)

Dialectical Behaviour Therapy (DBT) offers powerful skills for intense distress:

  • Temperature: Use cold (ice pack on face, cold shower) to activate 'dive reflex' and calm nervous system
  • Intense exercise: Sprint, jump, do burpees for 5-10 minutes to burn off adrenaline
  • Paced breathing: Slow breathing (5-6 breaths per minute)
  • Paired muscle relaxation: Tense and release muscle groups while breathing

Distress Tolerance Skills

When you can't change the situation, use these skills to survive intense emotions safely:

  • Distraction: Engage in activities (walk, puzzle, game, call friend)
  • Self-soothing: Use your senses (calming music, scented candle, soft blanket, favourite food, look at nature)
  • Improve the moment: Use imagery (safe place visualisation), prayer/mantra, focus on one thing mindfully
  • Pros and cons: List pros and cons of acting on the urge vs. using skills

Opposite Action

When emotions don't fit the facts or are unhelpful, act opposite to the emotion's urge:

  • Fear (not justified): Approach what you're afraid of (gradually)
  • Anger (not justified): Be kind, gentle, or step away
  • Sadness (not justified): Activate — do something engaging or productive
  • Shame (not justified): Share the experience with someone safe

Building Emotional Resilience

  • Self-care: Sleep, nutrition, exercise, social connection
  • Pleasant activities: Schedule at least one daily
  • Mastery activities: Do something that builds competence
  • Values-based living: Align actions with personal values
  • Mindfulness practice: Daily meditation, body scans, mindful movement

The Window of Tolerance

The 'window of tolerance' is the zone where you can manage emotions effectively. When outside this window:

  • Hyperarousal (above window): Anxiety, panic, anger, overwhelm → Use grounding, cold water, breathing
  • Hypoarousal (below window): Numbness, dissociation, shutdown → Use activation, movement, sensory input

The goal is to widen your window of tolerance over time through skill practice.

Emotional Regulation for Neurodivergent Individuals

ADHD

  • Emotional impulsivity is part of ADHD — use 'pause' strategies (count to 10, walk away)
  • Externalise emotions (write, draw, talk)
  • Use timers for cooling-off periods
  • Build in movement breaks to manage restlessness

Autism

  • Use visual supports (emotion thermometer, Zones of Regulation chart)
  • Create a sensory toolkit for regulation (fidgets, weighted items, music)
  • Identify and avoid overwhelming sensory triggers
  • Allow time for emotional processing — autistic individuals may need longer to recover

When to Seek Professional Help

Contact your GP or therapist if:

  • Emotional dysregulation is affecting daily life, work, or relationships
  • You're engaging in harmful coping behaviours (self-harm, substance use)
  • Emotions feel unmanageable despite self-help strategies
  • You're experiencing frequent emotional crises

Therapy Options

  • Dialectical Behaviour Therapy (DBT): Gold standard for emotional dysregulation
  • Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT): Identifying and changing thought patterns
  • EMDR or trauma therapy: If trauma is underlying cause
  • Mentalization-Based Therapy (MBT): Understanding your own and others' emotions

In a crisis: NHS 111 (option 2), Samaritans (116 123), SHOUT (text 85258), or 999 if at immediate risk.

Important Disclaimer

This information is for educational purposes and not a substitute for professional mental health care. Persistent emotional dysregulation or crisis situations require professional assessment and support. Consult your GP or mental health professional for personalised care.

posts.title: Reasonable Adjustments: Your Rights at Work and School (UK)
posts.excerpt: Comprehensive guide to requesting and implementing reasonable adjustments for neurodevelopmental and mental health conditions under UK law.
posts.contentHtml:
Understanding Reasonable Adjustments

Under the Equality Act 2010, schools, colleges, universities, and employers must make 'reasonable adjustments' for disabled people to remove barriers and ensure equal access.

Disability definition: A physical or mental impairment with a substantial and long-term (12+ months) negative effect on your ability to do normal daily activities. This includes many neurodevelopmental and mental health conditions.

What Are Reasonable Adjustments?

Reasonable adjustments are changes to remove or reduce disadvantage. They must be:

  • Reasonable in cost and practicality
  • Effective in removing the barrier
  • Specific to the individual's needs

Examples of adjustments: Changes to physical environment, equipment provision, policy changes, flexible working, extra time, assistive technology, modified tasks.

Reasonable Adjustments at School (England & Wales)

Your Child's Rights

Schools must make reasonable adjustments under the Equality Act 2010 and the SEND Code of Practice.

How to Request Adjustments

  • Contact the school's SENCO (Special Educational Needs Coordinator)
  • Provide evidence of need (diagnosis, medical letter, educational psychology report)
  • Discuss specific barriers your child faces
  • Propose adjustments (or ask the SENCO to suggest appropriate support)
  • Request adjustments in writing and keep records

Common School Adjustments

For ADHD:

  • Movement breaks during lessons
  • Preferential seating (away from distractions)
  • Fidget tools permitted
  • Written instructions provided alongside verbal
  • Extra time for tasks and exams
  • Use of laptop for writing

For Autism:

  • Visual timetables and advance notice of changes
  • Access to a quiet space for breaks
  • Modified sensory environment (lighting, noise)
  • Clear, direct communication
  • Social skills support or social group
  • Flexible attendance for medical appointments

For Dyslexia:

  • Dyslexia-friendly fonts and materials
  • Access to text-to-speech and speech-to-text software
  • Extra time in exams (typically 25%)
  • Reader or scribe in exams
  • Reduced copying from board
  • Specialist dyslexia tuition

For Anxiety/Mental Health:

  • Flexibility with attendance or deadlines (within reason)
  • Access to quiet space when overwhelmed
  • Modified PE participation if needed
  • Regular check-ins with pastoral support
  • Exam access arrangements (separate room, extra time)

EHCP (Education, Health and Care Plan)

If adjustments aren't sufficient, request an EHCP assessment via your local authority. EHCPs are legally binding plans detailing support and provision for children with complex needs (ages 0-25).

Reasonable Adjustments at Work (UK)

Your Rights

Employers must make reasonable adjustments under the Equality Act 2010 if you meet the definition of disability.

How to Request Adjustments

  • Disclose your condition to your line manager or HR (you're not legally required to disclose, but adjustments require disclosure)
  • Provide medical evidence if requested (GP letter, occupational health report)
  • Clearly explain the barriers you face and proposed adjustments
  • Request adjustments in writing and keep copies
  • If refused, ask for written reasons (adjustments must be 'reasonable')

Common Workplace Adjustments

For ADHD:

  • Flexible working hours (e.g., later start time)
  • Regular breaks and movement permitted
  • Quiet workspace or noise-cancelling headphones
  • Written meeting agendas and follow-up notes
  • Use of task management apps or reminders
  • Reduced open-plan workspace noise

For Autism:

  • Clear, direct communication (written confirmation of tasks)
  • Advance notice of meetings or changes
  • Flexible working location (remote work, quiet office)
  • Adjustments to social expectations (e.g., optional team events)
  • Sensory adjustments (lighting, desk location)

For Mental Health Conditions:

  • Flexible hours or part-time working
  • Phased return to work after illness
  • Regular supervision or check-ins
  • Reduced workload during difficult periods
  • Time off for medical appointments
  • Access to Employee Assistance Programme (EAP)

Access to Work

Access to Work is a UK government scheme providing grants for workplace adjustments, including:

  • Assistive technology and software
  • Workplace needs assessment
  • Support worker or job coach
  • Adaptations to premises or equipment
  • Travel to work if you can't use public transport

Apply at: www.gov.uk/access-to-work

Your Rights if Adjustments Are Refused

If an employer or school refuses adjustments:

  1. Ask for written reasons
  2. Check if the refusal is justified (is it genuinely unreasonable in cost or practicality?)
  3. Escalate: speak to HR, senior leadership, school governors, or trustees
  4. Seek advice from ACAS (workplace), IPSEA (education), or Equality Advisory Support Service (EASS)
  5. Consider formal complaint or legal action (discrimination claim under Equality Act)

Support Organisations (UK)

  • ACAS: Workplace rights advice (0300 123 1100)
  • IPSEA: Education law and SEND support (0800 018 4016)
  • Equality Advisory Support Service (EASS): Equality Act advice (0808 800 0082)
  • Citizens Advice: General rights and discrimination advice

Adjustments at University

Universities must make reasonable adjustments under the Equality Act. Contact your university's Disability Service to:

  • Request a needs assessment
  • Access Disabled Students' Allowance (DSA) for funding
  • Arrange exam access arrangements
  • Access note-taking support, mentoring, or assistive technology

When to Seek Advice

Contact a support organisation if:

  • Your request for adjustments is refused without good reason
  • You experience discrimination or unfair treatment
  • You're unsure what adjustments to request
  • You need help navigating the process

Important Disclaimer

This information is for educational purposes and not legal advice. Equality and disability law is complex and individual circumstances vary. Consult ACAS, IPSEA, EASS, or a legal professional for case-specific guidance.
